div1.p: Bauvallet reports on the use of Noguchi serum and vaccine to treat yellow fever cases in Bassam, Ivory Coast.

div1.head: English translation [from French] of a report extract: Report on the yellow fever epidemic in Grand Bassam, by [s.n.] Bauvallet, October 25, 1922 (See French original.)
div1.p:
Extract from a report by Dr. Bauvallet on the use of the Noguchi
serum and vaccine during the yellow fever epidemic in Bassam
(Ivory Coast) in French West Africa in 1922. (1)

Report on the yellow fever epidemic in Grand Bassam,
August 18 - September 8, 1922.

The physician stationed in Bassam, which is a city
particularly exposed to epidemics, had already entered into
personal correspondence with Mr. Hideyo Noguchi of the Rocke-
feller Institute in 1921, and had received from him early in
1922 a certain amount of anti-yellow-fever serum and vaccine
preserved in ice.

At the very beginning of the epidemic a circular
letter was published informing the inhabitants that anyone who
wished it would be vaccinated in accord with the results
published by the eminent Japanese biologist.

From August 18 to 24, 140 Europeans out of a population
of about 200 were vaccinated with dead cultures of Leptospira
incteroides from lot 15, prepared on December 9, 1921. One
hundred and thirty-one received two injections of 2 cc. at an
interval of 6 days, according to the author's technique; 9 did
not appear for the second injection.

Practically all of the persons vaccinated presented
the following reaction on the evening of the day on which they
had received the injection between 8 and 10 A.M.; light fever
with pain in the small of the back, more or less marked rachialgia,
typical picture of the “coup de barre”, consisting of very severe

(1) This serum and vaccine had been sent directly to Dr. Bauvallet by
the Rockefeller Institute, to which he had sent anatomical specimens.
4.
pain in the lumbar region. The intensity of the rachialgia was
what kept 8 of the 9 that had the first injection from returning for
the second. The ninth of these persons is mentioned in a special
report at the end of this one.

Four of the persons vaccinated presented sterile abcesses,
indicated by Noguchi as being due to the presence of agar-agar in
the culture medium, after 15-20 days and appearing at the point of
innoculation in spite of systematic massage immediately after the
penetration of the skin by the vaccine. These abcesses were cured
by simple cupping and left no scars.

At the same time serotherapy with Noguchi's serum, kept at
a temperature of minus 4 degrees Centigrade, was applied to all the
patients, in addition to the classical and purely symptomatic treatment.

The results of this serotherapy were as follows:
Case No.1, - The diagnosis of yellow fever was not absolute
until the appearance of the black vomit. The patient received im-
mediately, at 4:30 P.M., an intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum.
Death occurred at 5.43 P.M. This injection was given in extremis,
after the third day, when it is said by Noguchi to be no longer of
any value.
Case. 2. - The disease made its appearance in the evening
of August 18, with a very high fever. The patient said that he
had had a temperature of 39.9 degrees C. at the time. The case
was not reported until the next morning, when the patient was
isolated in the Ambulance hospital. Pain in the back, “coup de
barre”, congestion of the face, epigrastralgia, scant urine with
5.
no albumen. Temperature of 39.4. Received 60 cc. of serum at
8.30 A.M. Decrease in temperature and diuresis in the afternoon;
cure.
Case 3. - High fever during the night of the 17-18.
Seen by the physician on the 18th at 9 A.M. Temperature of 39.2,
extreme pain in the lumbar region, cramps in the legs, bilious
vomit and internal epigastralgia, albuminaria. Received 60 cc.
of serum intravenously. The temperature fell to 38.6 in the
afternoon. Decrease in the vomiting, appearance of a subicteric
condition that persisted until August 24. Disappearance of the
albuminuria; defervescence; cure.
Case 4. - Patient fell ill on August 15, but her husband did
not call a physician, as he thought that it was merely a fever due
to acclimatization. Isolated only in the evening of the 17th,
actually later than case 1, although the symptoms suggested a
malarial attack. On the 19th the diagnosis became evident; slight
uterine hemorrhages, epigastralgia, bilious vomit, congestion of
the face, prostration, subicterus, scant urine with albumen. Was
given an intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum. On the 20th
the icterus was general and the prostration still more marked;
there were subcutaneous sanguineous effusions and the anuria was
total. A second intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum was
administered; a few drops of very albuminous urine were expelled
after the injection. Death at 7:10 P.M. The serotherapeutic
treatment was late and useless.
Case 5. - The patient took to bed on the 21st about
6.
10 A.M. Was seen at once and sent to the Ambulance hospital
to be isolated. No pain in the lumbar region, but epigastralgia,
bilious vomit. congestion of the face. The temperature remained
at from 39.2 to 39.6 during the whole day of the 21st. The
patient passed a restless night, with a temperature of 39.8 at
7 A.M. on the 22nd. Received 60 cc. of serum less than 4 hours
after the beginning of the disease. The vomiting continued and
was tinged with blood. Death at 1:45 P.M. The treatment was not
totally unsuccessful; autopsy was not performed on account of lack
of time.

One case must receive special mention, that of the ninth
person who had only one injection.

Mr. B..., living at the Atlantic Hotel, and a neighbor
of Mr. X... and Mr. Y... received 2 cc. of vaccine on August 22, but did not appear for the second injection on the 23rd. The
proprietor of the Atlantic Hotel, on being asked over the telephone
as to why Mr. B... remained absent, replied guardedly that Mr. B...
was not well. The patient was seen at 10:30 A.M. He had had no reaction
after the first injection, but on the night of the 27-28 he had a fever
and a back-ache. He did not take his temperature at the time. When
seen his temperature was 39.2, “coup de barre”, cramps in the legs,
congestion of the face that was in marked contrast to his usual pallor,
gums edged with white, a symptom that appeared only in this case,
vomiting, albuminaria. Was isolated in the Ambulance hospital, and
received an intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum at 1 P.M. The
7.
patient immediately presented an intense seric reaction, pruritus,
generalized erythrosis, very grave syncope. An intravenous injection
of 1 mg. of adrenaline caused the disappearance of the analhylactic
phenomena. The fever and the disturbing symptoms disappeared during
the night.
